Award.AwardTitle: IOLAB: Using Technology to Transform Introductory Physics Labs

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project is developing, evaluating, and disseminating an innovative online approach to interactive laboratory learning for introductory physics courses. SmartLab allows students to measure things in the real world by facilitating hands-on experiments anywhere - in their home, in their dorm, in their classroom - guided and evaluated by the SmartLab learning software and online database. At the heart of the SmartLab approach is a small and inexpensive wireless probe, developed in collaboration with private industry, which has the ability to rapidly perform accurate measurements of displacement, velocity, acceleration, force, magnetic fields, and potential differences. These data are sent over a wireless link to a PC running the SmartLab application which also communicates with an online database to retrieve carefully designed lesson plans. The software guides students through the lesson, recording and analyzing the data they acquire, and provides real-time feedback on the student's performance of the hands-on activities as well as the student's answers to questions embedded in the lesson.

A primary focus of NSF support for this project is a physics education research effort to practically optimize the SmartLab approach while studying the pros and cons of differing methods of utilization. Researchers are determining how the retention of key physics concepts is impacted by hands-on SmartLab activities, as they are performed at nearly the same time as the conceptual introduction. Such research plays a key role in building a sound pedagogical footing for this new approach in universities, colleges and high schools.

SmartLab enables a complete hands-on laboratory experience for students to perform at a time and place that maximizes the learning experience, whether this is before a lecture, part of a weekly homework assignment, or during an existing lab period. In addition to providing a powerful tool for traditional physics courses, SmartLab has tremendous potential for courses which currently do not offer a hands-on experience, such as those taken by students online, or courses where budget or space constraints preclude a lab. The inherently scalable nature of the SmartLab approach, combined with the fact that it can be adopted by faculty members with a very modest investment in time and resources, means its impact on American physics education may become significant on a short timescale.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The ideal function of laboratory activities in the context of introductory physics is to provide students with tangible ways of understanding the abstract concepts discussed in the other components of the class, and to help them develop the scientific abilities required to design their own experiments, draw conclusions from their data, and communicate their results. All too often the traditional laboratory component of a course falls short of this ideal, however. Because of limitations imposed by both time and equipment, lab activities are often procedural in nature, and students are unable to focus on real conceptual learning or on scientific skills. Even worse, less confident students can become discouraged and fall into passive roles within their lab groups, watching their lab partners doing the assigned activities rather than risk slowing them down by trying to understand the material at their own pace.

 

Researchers in the Department of Physics at the University of Illinois, working with the support of an industrial partner (Macmillan Publishing), have developed IOLab—an innovative system that combines an inexpensive and portable data acquisition device with powerful free software and an online data repository. This system gives each student control of a potent and easy-to-use lab system that they can use to do experiments at his or her own pace, in homes or dorm rooms as well as in lab classes (see www.iolab.science for more details, software, and links to instructional videos and other shared resources). The initial goal of this NSF-funded project was to explore, assess, and disseminate ways in which the IOLab system could be used to address the limitations of traditional labs and improve introductory physics learning outcomes for our students.

 

The project has succeeded beyond all original expectations. We have piloted a new and successful approach to introductory physics labs at the University of Illinois, involving students in both the engineering and life-science curricula. This lab reform effort has become a focus of our department’s undergraduate teaching program and will continue past the end of this grant, eventually impacting all of our introductory courses. In addition, other institutions have shown strong interest in developing their own content and pedagogies centered on IOLab, and the growing community of active users has become a key outcome of the program. The system is currently in use by educators at many universities, community colleges, and high schools across the United States and Canada, and by several institutions in Europe, Scandinavia, and Asia. Instructional activities and pedagogies based on IOLab are being disseminated and shared by the growing community of users at major international education conferences as well as at state and local professional-development workshops.

The pedagogies enabled by IOLab are on track to become scalable core elements for transforming introductory physics labs into authentic experiences in which students can develop scientific reasoning and experimental design skills as well as physical intuition for difficult concepts. It seems quite certain that the positive impact of this grant will continue to grow even as the initial support provided by the National Science Foundation draws to its natural end.
